abstract.p: M Lester O'Shea letter on September 3 article on lack of diversity among top executives at G E questions why race or sex matters but other attributes apparently do not (S)

block.p: ''Where G.E. Falls Short: Diversity at the Top'' (Sept. 3) left me shaking my head. While genuine diversity, in attributes and background, can be a real plus for a company, why should race or sex matter? Segregationists thought people were defined by race, but didn't sensible people know better?

''Where G.E. Falls Short: Diversity at the Top'' (Sept. 3) left me shaking my head. While genuine diversity, in attributes and background, can be a real plus for a company, why should race or sex matter? Segregationists thought people were defined by race, but didn't sensible people know better?
And why stop there? Are there enough executives of Italian or Polish heritage? Does G.E. have the right percentages of Jews, Catholics and Southern Baptists?

Unless the company has reason to suspect that it is promoting the wrong people because better-qualified women and minorities are being rejected, it's hard to see any rational basis for G.E. concerning itself with the race or sex of those it promotes, let alone engaging in race and sex discrimination to enlarge certain groups' representation.
M. LESTER O'SHEA Walnut Creek, Calif., Sept. 12
